G.L. c. 186.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant has been Plaintiff’s landlord within the meaning of G.L. c. 186 and applicable Massachusetts common law.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: G.L. c. 186, § 14 provides that a landlord who breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment “shall also be liable for actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee.”

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in Lowell District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19, because the Premises are located in Lowell, Massachusetts, and the acts and omissions complained of occurred in this Court’s territorial jurisdiction.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court under G.L. c. 223, § 2, because Plaintiff’s tenancy is located in Lowell, Middlesex County, Massachusetts.

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq..proposition: Under the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., a landlord must maintain rented premises in a habitable condition, free from conditions that may endanger or materially impair the health or safety of the occupants.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B and/or \u00a7 6C.proposition: An award of damages pursuant to G.L. c. 186, § 14 in an amount not less than three (3) months’ rent, i.e., $3,600, or Plaintiff’s actual and consequential damages, whichever is greater, together with interest as allowed by law under G.L. c. 231, § 6B and/or § 6C;

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: A landlord’s failure to maintain the premises in compliance with the State Sanitary Code, where such failure substantially interferes with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises or threatens the tenant’s health or safety, can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The case recognizes that a landlord’s conduct (acts, omissions, or what is permitted) that substantially interferes with a tenant’s use and enjoyment can breach the covenant of quiet enjoyment, but it does so in the context of excessive noise from a lounge, not failure to comply with the State Sanitary Code. The opinion does not discuss the State Sanitary Code, health/safety code violations, or how such violations might constitute a breach. Thus, while conceptually related, it does not provide authority for the specific sanitary-code-based proposition stated.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: A landlord’s failure to maintain the premises in compliance with the State Sanitary Code, where such failure substantially interferes with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises or threatens the tenant’s health or safety, can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The court repeatedly links the landlord’s statutory and common‑law obligation to maintain sanitary, watertight conditions with the tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment. It holds that Gem is liable under G.L. c. 186, § 14 because it violated its duty to maintain sanitary conditions and thereby permitted repeated flooding that interfered with Solomon’s quiet enjoyment, explicitly tying State Sanitary Code compliance to quiet enjoyment where the conditions substantially interfered with use and posed health/safety concerns.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The water in Solomon’s apartment was a preventable situation, and one that Gem had a duty to prevent. See 105 Code Mass. Regs. 410.500; Crowell v. McCaffrey, 377 Mass. 443 (1979); Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973). The jury found in answer to a special question… that the water interfered with Solomon’s quiet enjoyment of her apartment. Therefore, Gem is liable under G. L. c. 186, § 14… Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: A landlord’s failure to maintain the premises in compliance with the State Sanitary Code, where such failure substantially interferes with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises or threatens the tenant’s health or safety, can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The opinion does discuss G.L. c. 186, § 14 and cites prior cases where failure to repair code-related defects violated the covenant of quiet enjoyment, but this case’s holding is narrow: it addresses whether a *strict-liability* violation of the lead paint statute, by itself, constitutes a § 14 violation, and answers no. The court requires at least negligent conduct plus notice or reason to know; it does not articulate or focus on the broader proposition that any State Sanitary Code noncompliance substantially interfering with use or threatening health is itself a breach of quiet enjoyment. That broader rule is only indirectly referenced via citations to other cases, not established by this decision.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: We noted that a landlord’s failure “to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.” See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so). Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord…

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: A landlord’s failure to maintain the premises in compliance with the State Sanitary Code, where such failure substantially interferes with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises or threatens the tenant’s health or safety, can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The opinion directly ties the landlord’s statutory duty to provide heat—embodied in the State Sanitary Code—to the covenant of quiet enjoyment, holding that failure to provide heat during the heating season “constitutes a breach” of that covenant. While the court focuses on heat, it does so by reference to the Sanitary Code and describes the failure as seriously impairing the character and value of the premises, which fits within substantial interference with use and enjoyment and threat to health/safety. Thus the case supports using Sanitary Code noncompliance (here, lack of heat) as a basis for a quiet enjoyment breach.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season (see State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. §§ 410.201, 410.750 [B] [1980]) seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’ … and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See generally Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715-716 (1977), and cases cited.”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: A landlord’s failure to maintain the premises in compliance with the State Sanitary Code, where such failure substantially interferes with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises or threatens the tenant’s health or safety, can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The case recognizes that a landlord’s omissions regarding security and control of criminal activity in common areas can, if they cause serious interference, constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. However, the court expressly limits this analysis to G.L. c. 186, § 14 and does not ground the quiet enjoyment holding in the State Sanitary Code or in a failure to maintain premises in compliance with that Code. The opinion also treats Sanitary Code compliance as part of the warranty of habitability analysis, and it rejects expanding that warranty to cover the security problems at issue, so it does not stand for the specific sanitary-code-based proposition stated.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that the implied warranty of habitability is concerned with the provision, maintenance, and repair of the physical facilities vital to the use of the leased premises, and is not breached solely by the presence on the premises of uninvited persons engaged in unlawful activities or by the failure to provide security services.… If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: Exposure to mold and damp, unsanitary conditions that adversely affect respiratory health materially impairs the character and value of the tenancy, and constitutes a substantial interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns repeated loss of heat and hot water and addresses breach of the implied warranty of habitability and rent abatement. It does not discuss mold, dampness, unsanitary conditions affecting respiratory health, or interference with quiet enjoyment as such. While it recognizes that substantial State Sanitary Code violations can render a dwelling uninhabitable, it is not authority specifically for mold-related or dampness-related conditions constituting a substantial interference with quiet enjoyment.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “‘[T]he essential objective of the leasing transaction is to provide a dwelling suitable for habitation.’ Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, supra at 196-197. A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable. The essential objective of the warranty is to make sure that the tenant receives what she is paying for.”

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782.proposition: Exposure to mold and damp, unsanitary conditions that adversely affect respiratory health materially impairs the character and value of the tenancy, and constitutes a substantial interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782.support_reasoning: The opinion does find a violation of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, based on severe sanitary code violations, but it does not mention mold, dampness, or respiratory health. The court speaks in general terms about numerous sanitary, building, and fire code violations—heat, hot water, vermin, unsanitary common areas—impairing the value of the premises and constituting a substantial interference with quiet enjoyment. Thus, it supports the broader principle that serious unsanitary and code-violating conditions that materially impair the value of the tenancy violate quiet enjoyment, but it does not specifically support the mold/respiratory-health formulation in the proposition.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782.relevant_excerpt: “Decisions from this court and from the Appeals Court clearly support the imposition of civil liability under § 14 in circumstances like those present in this case. In Ianello v. Court Management Corp., 400 Mass. 321, 323 (1987), it was said that a landlord violates § 14 when his acts or omissions impair the value of the leased premises.… Cruz Management had notice of numerous sanitary, building and fire code violations… [T]he failure adequately to correct these violations, which included inadequate heat and hot water and a serious infestation of vermin, would impair substantially the value of the leased premises as a dwelling place… On the facts found by the judge a violation of § 14 has been shown.”

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: The presence of mold and Defendant’s refusal to adequately remedy it also amount to a violation of the State Sanitary Code, which in turn supports a claim of breach of quiet enjoyment.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: This opinion (specifically a concurrence/dissent) is focused on implied warranty of habitability and the effect of State Sanitary Code violations on rent liability and eviction, not on breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. While it repeatedly treats sanitary code violations as legally cognizable defects that can reduce rent or support tenant remedies, it does not discuss G.L. c. 186, § 14 or otherwise tie such violations to a claim for breach of quiet enjoyment. Using this case as authority that mold constituting a Sanitary Code violation supports a quiet-enjoyment claim therefore overstates what Hemingway decides.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “Since 1960 dwelling units have been subject to the State Sanitary Code… The Code… fixes minimum standards of fitness of structures for human habitation… It expressly places the burden on the owner to comply with the prescribed minimum physical standards for rented dwelling units… I would… hold… that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards….”

Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.raw_text: Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744 (2005)
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord’s persistent failure, after notice, to remedy sanitary code violations or conditions threatening a tenant’s health and safety constitutes an “act or omission” that directly or indirectly interrupts or interferes with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment in violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the covenant and statutory right of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, but only to hold that there was no violation because the landlord acted promptly to correct conditions once notified and there was no serious interference with the tenant’s tenancy. It does not state or imply that a landlord’s persistent failure after notice to remedy sanitary or dangerous conditions constitutes an act or omission interfering with quiet enjoyment; instead, it finds the opposite on these facts. Thus, the case does not provide authority for the proposition asserted, even though it is consistent with the general framework that serious interferences can violate § 14.
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.relevant_excerpt: “Similar to the warranty of habitability, during the rental of any residential premises, there exists an implied covenant and a statutory right of quiet enjoyment. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1982); G. L. c. 186, § 14. We have interpreted this obligation to mean that the covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant from serious interference with her tenancy. See Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Authy., 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994). Generally, the landlord must have had notice of the condition interfering with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises, and he must have at least acted negligently in not alleviating the condition.”

Figueroa v. Ponce, 89 Mass. App. Ct. 112.raw_text: Figueroa v. Ponce, 89 Mass. App. Ct. 1121 (2016) (Rule 1:28 decision)
Figueroa v. Ponce, 89 Mass. App. Ct. 112.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord’s persistent failure, after notice, to remedy sanitary code violations or conditions threatening a tenant’s health and safety constitutes an “act or omission” that directly or indirectly interrupts or interferes with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment in violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14.
